revision.text:
''[[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]]'' is an online team-based [[first person shooter]] developed by [[Blizzard Entertainment]], and released worldwide in May 2016. Normally played in matches of six-vs-six, players select from one of [[Characters of Overwatch|29 heroes]], broadly classified into the three categories of Tank, Damage, and Support, and work with their team to attack or defend map objectives. Each hero has a unique set of weapons, abilities, and skills, which players can coordinate to overpower the other team. ''Overwatch'' supports both casual and ranked matchmaking, as well as a rotating set of arcade modes, and the game has since become a popular [[eSport]], featuring a professional [[Overwatch League]] that started in 2018. The game has been both a critical and financial success for Blizzard, exceeding over 30 million players and obtaining over $1 billion in revenue within its first year.
To support ongoing interest in the game, Blizzard has run several seasonal events, typically coinciding with worldwide events and holidays. These events last for two to three weeks, updating [[Level (video gaming)|levels]] to incorporate elements of that theme, and provide new game modes along with the opportunity to acquire unique cosmetic options. Players keep their earned character cosmetic options after the event ends, but the rest of the themed elements return to normal.
== Overview == Over the course of developing ''Overwatch'', Blizzard opted against using a [[downloadable content]] model to extend the game and bring post-sale revenues, as they had developed the game around the mechanic of allowing players to switch out to new heroes during the course of a match as to meet current strategic conditions; by requiring players to purchase new heroes, such a model would have hampered this approach.<ref name="Ars Technica: Development"/> Instead, they opted to include [[microtransaction]]s through which players can buy [[loot box]]es, which contain four randomized cosmetic items, including characters skins, victory poses, emotes, spray tags, highlight introductions, and player icons. This allowed them to create an incentivized [[experience level|level progression system]] that would reward players with a loot box for every level they earned from experience gained in playing matches.<ref name="PCGamesN: Progression"/> Working alongside this, players can earn in-game coins through some loot box rewards or as a consolation prize for receiving a duplicate loot box reward. These coins can be used to purchase any of the available cosmetic items (with the exception of player icons), the cost reflecting the rarity of obtaining the item through a loot box.
Beginning in August 2016, Blizzard began introducing seasonal events, starting with the Summer Games event which corresponded with the [[2016 Summer Olympics]]. ''Overwatch''{{'}}s director Jeff Kaplan said the goal of these seasonal events was to make the game "feel alive", correlating with real-world events.<ref name="VG247: Seasonal"/> The company has a history of creating in-game seasonal events, such as the Valentine's Day and New Year's events in ''[[World of Warcraft]]''. Other competitor games, such as ''[[Destiny (video game)|Destiny]]'', ''[[League of Legends]]'' and ''[[Team Fortress 2]]'', also implement in-game seasonal events.<ref name="IGN: more"/>
Events have generally included at least one new game mode, which typically is only available to play while that event is active; one exception is the "Capture the Flag" mode introduced during the Chinese New Year event in early 2017, which has been brought back to the game as a permanent feature in the game's casual Arcade matchmaking mode. Players are typically rewarded with loot boxes for playing matches in these seasonal game modes, and the game offers unique [[achievement (video gaming)|achievements]] and associated cosmetic rewards for completing certain goals within them.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mic.com/articles/173914/overwatch-uprising-achievements-how-to-unlock-all-the-new-event-sprays#.m0kj9F4sw|title=How to unlock all the new 'Overwatch' sprays during the Uprising event|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en}}</ref>
In addition to new games modes, these seasonal events include unique cosmetic items that can be obtained primarily during the event. Blizzard develops a large amount of content for these events, not all which ends up available to players.<ref name="USGamer: Events 2017"/> Initially, these items could only be obtained through event-themed loot boxes that are guaranteed to contain at least one event-themed item, which could either be earned through leveling up, completing the event game modes, or through microtransactions;<ref name="IGN: Summer release"/><ref name="Polygon: Summer"/> however, in response to player feedback and avoid an apparent [[paywall]] access to these items, Blizzard allowed players to purchase these items with in-game currency at a higher cost than a non-event item of the same rarity, starting from the second seasonal event onward.<ref name="PC Gamer: Halloween"/><ref name="IGN: Summer Problem"/> When the event is completed, the themed loot boxes and cosmetic items are no longer are available until the event is run again. However, players retain and can use all unique event items they have earned after the event.<ref name="IGN: Summer release"/> Not all event items will be limited in this manner, as Blizzard plans to have certain event items be possible loot obtained from a regular loot box in the future.<ref name="Kotatu: Special Skins to Regular Loot"/>
Several seasonal events, such as Summer Games, Halloween Terror, and Winter Wonderland, have recurred. However, on bringing these events back, the development team has added new changes to the event to keep them fresh and to reflect any new heroes or other content added to the game since the previous event's occurrence; for example, the 2017 Halloween "Junkenstein's Revenge" included a new endless mode and support for some of the newer heroes.<ref name="PCGamesN: Returning Seasonal"/> Recurring events also feature new themed cosmetic items for these recurring events, along with the return of the previous cosmetics which can be found in the event loot boxes or bought for a reduced coin amount.<ref name="Polygon: Summer 2017"/> Not all seasonal events are designed for recurrence, such as the lore-heavy "Uprising" event which took place in April 2017. Kaplan said that Blizzard has plans as to how these events will evolve in the future.<ref name="PCGamesN: Winter 2017"/>
== 2016 events == === Summer Games ===
In August 2016, Blizzard released its first seasonal event in celebration of the concurrent [[2016 Summer Olympics]]. Both Blizzard's "Summer Games" and the Olympics ran throughout the month. Summer Games added 100 new cosmetic character options and a new game mode, Lúcioball.<ref name="IGN: Summer release"/>
Lúcioball was designed as a futuristic [[soccer]] game in which two teams of three Lúcio characters attempt to push a ball into their opponents' goal. Played in four-minute matches on the special stadium map, Estádio das Rãs, players use two kinds of attacks to control the ball's movements: primarily, a melee attack and a secondary, powerful sonic boom that could knock back opponents as well (frequently called "booping" by players). Players can also use the level's environmental perks (e.g., jump pads and speed-boosting walls) to secure strategic advantage on the field.<ref name="IGN: Summer release"/> ''PC Gamer'' felt that the mode felt closer to a "multiplayer carnival game than a fleshed-out, standalone mode".<ref name="PC Gamer: Junkenstein"/>
=== Halloween Terror ===
Blizzard released its second seasonal event for [[Halloween]], which lasted throughout the month of October 2016. It included over 100 new cosmetic items (in [[jack-o'-lantern]]-themed loot boxes) and the game's first [[player versus environment|game mode against computer players]], Junkenstein's Revenge.<ref name="PC Gamer: Terror now"/> Several characters received new Halloween-themed cosmetic skins. ''PC Gamer'' wrote that they were among the game's best add-ons,<ref name="PC Gamer: Halloween"/> and ''[[Kill Screen]]'' felt the new character skins were much more enjoyable compared to those offered for the Summer Games.<ref name="Kill Screen: Halloween"/> Players could now purchase the seasonal add-ons with in-game credits (at a premium), in response to criticism Blizzard received from players during the Summer Games.<ref name="PC Gamer: Terror now"/>
In Junkenstein's Revenge, four players [[co-op video game|cooperatively]] guard a castle door from oncoming waves of enemies and [[Boss (video gaming)|bosses]]. Set in a themed section of the game's Eichenwalde map, players select a [[difficulty level]] and choose between the characters [[Ana (Overwatch)|Ana]], [[Hanzo (Overwatch)|Hanzo]], [[McCree (Overwatch)|McCree]], and [[Soldier:_76]], before fighting off approaching mindless "zomnic" drones, long-range "zombardiers," exploding tires, and costumed versions of the characters [[Reaper (Overwatch)|Reaper]], [[Roadhog (Overwatch)|Roadhog]], [[Symmetra (Overwatch)|Symmetra]], [[Mercy (Overwatch)|Mercy]], and [[Junkrat]] (as the titular Dr. Junkenstein).<ref name="PC Gamer: Junkenstein"/> The game mode includes new voice work and is based on a companion comic book released concurrently.<ref name="PC Gamer: Junkenstein"/>
The new mode was generally praised by commentators. ''[[PC Gamer]]'' wrote that the event resembled a similar event run on the team shooter ''Team Fortress 2'' since 2012. Though the reviewer found the Junkenstein mode pleasant, he wrote that in comparison to ''Team Fortress 2''{{'s}} [[Mann vs. Machine]] mode, Junkenstein felt "shallow" and similar to Lúcioball in its simplistic map flow, giving little room for player movement. He also wondered why the mode was limited to four specific characters.<ref name="PC Gamer: Junkenstein"/> ''[[Eurogamer]]''{{'}}s Robert Purchase found the event fun and considered it a good distraction from ''Overwatch''{{'}}s main modes, but also recognized that if it was kept on after the Halloween Terror event, it would become a stale game mode.<ref name="Eurogamer: Halloween"/> Heather Alexandra for ''[[Kotaku]]'' felt that the mode demonstrated that a co-operative player-versus-environment mode would fit well as a permanent feature within ''Overwatch'' as it required good team coordination to complete more challenging matches.<ref name="Kotaku: Halloween"/>
The event ended a few hours earlier than had been planned, leaving some players upset as they were waiting for as long as possible collecting the themed loot boxes in-game before trying to spend in-game coins or purchasing loot boxes to get the cosmetic items they were missing.<ref name="Kotaku: Halloween early end"/>
=== Winter Wonderland === The holiday-themed Winter Wonderland event ran for the latter half of December 2016 through the first days of the new year. Like previous events, it added over 100 themed cosmetic items for players to obtain via loot boxes or in-game currency, as well as provided snowy versions of two of the game's maps.<ref name="Polygon: Winter"/> One cosmetic items included the first Legendary skin for Mei since the game's release, a Santa-like outfit; with this skin equipped, it also changed the appearance of Mei's Cryo-Freeze from a simple block of ice to a frozen snowman.<ref name="Polygon: Winter Mei"/> Players criticized the skin, feeling that it did not vary as much from Mei's normal outfits and appeared to be a simple recoloring of her default skin, in comparison to what other characters' Legendary skins had been.<ref name="Polygon: Winter Mei"/> Blizzard admitted that their "'cool meter' was off" when they designed this skin, believing that players would take to the Cryo-Freeze effect as a reason to value the skin. Blizzard stated that they had plans for another Mei Legendary skin, along the lines of what players would expect, in early 2017.<ref name="Polygon: Winter Mei Response"/>
The event featured a new [[deathmatch]] mode called "Mei's Snowball Offensive". The mode took place on the smaller Ecopoint: Antartica map, introduced in the previous months for standard deathmatch play. Six players each play Mei, but where her Endothermic Blaster, which normally fires a stream of damaging cold, can only fire a single snowball. Players must find a snowball pile scattered around the map to reload the weapon. Further, her Ultimate ability allows her to fire a machine-gun-like string of snowballs for a brief period. Otherwise, Mei's other abilities (Ice Wall and Cyro-Freeze) remain the same. A single snowball hit kills the struck until the round is complete.<ref name="Polygon: Winter"/> Kotaku claims this mode was generally not well received by players as the act of having to reload the Blaster made one too vulnerable, and with the [[permadeath]] mechanic in play, the mode was not fun nor captured the spirit of a snowball fight.<ref name="Kotaku: Winter"/>
== 2017 events == === Year of the Rooster === A [[Chinese New Year]]-themed event launched a few days before the actual holiday on January 28, 2017, and centered on celebrating the Year of the [[Rooster (zodiac)|Rooster]]. As with past events, the Chinese New Year event introduced over 100 new cosmetic items, including the promised new Legendary skin for Mei to make up for the poorly-received one she had gotten during the Winter Wonderland event.<ref name="Polygon: CNY"/> Other skins for Roadhog, Reinhardt, Winston and Zenyatta alluded to the Chinese novel ''[[Journey to the West]]''.<ref name="Polygon: CNY Leak"/>
The event introduced the first [[Capture the Flag]] mode for ''Overwatch'' called "Capture the Rooster"; Blizzard had looked at adding such a mode for a few years during ''Overwatch''{{'}}s development but had difficulty with the mechanics due to the vastly different set of abilities offered by the characters that could imbalance the mode towards fast-moving characters.<ref name="Polygon: CTF"/> Played on the Lijiang Tower map, normally used for Control modes, each team has a flag near their base. To capture the other opponent's flag, a character must stay near the flag and not take damage for a few seconds. Once they have taken the flag, they then must return it to their team's base, scoring a point if they do so. If they die while bringing the flag back, either a teammate can try to capture it, or the opposing team must stay near the flag, avoiding taking damage for a few seconds, to return it to their base. Teams can score with the opposing team's flag even if their team's flag has been taken. The first team to three scores, or the team with the highest score after five minutes, wins the match.<ref name="Polygon: CNY Start"/>
Following the event, Blizzard introduced a more general Capture the Flag mode, playable on any of the Control maps, into the Arcade modes as well as making it an option for custom games with several adjustable parameters.<ref name="Polygon: CTF added"/>
=== ''Overwatch'' Archive: Uprising === Uprising ran for most of the month of April 2017, and was the first seasonal event not tied to any real-world event, but instead used to expand the lore of ''Overwatch''. The story centered around one of the last official missions of the Overwatch team before they were disbanded—having to end the threat of a hostile Omnic force known as the Null Sector in its attack on the citizens of London—; which also happened to be [[Tracer (Overwatch)|Tracer]]'s first mission. Over 100 new cosmetic items were added with this event, many based on the uniforms and backstory of the original Overwatch forces.<ref name="Polygon: Uprising"/> A digital comic retelling this story was released alongside the event.<ref name="VG247: Uprising"/> According to Kaplan, the Uprising event was something Blizzard felt had been asked for by players since they started offering the seasonal events. Players had requested non-holiday-themed events, as well as sought more details on the setting and history of the ''Overwatch'' world.<ref name="VG247: Uprising"/>
The event added a new cooperative player-versus-environment mode called "Uprising", played on the King's Row map set in London. In the standard mode, which can be played at one of four difficulty levels, four players select from the characters of Tracer, [[Reinhardt (Overwatch)|Reinhardt]], [[Torbjörn (Overwatch)|Torbjörn]], and Mercy. From there, the players are directed by in-game narration to take several control points while fighting against waves of Null Sector Omnics that try to stop them. Eventually, they must then escort an explosive weapon to a sealed door in order to access the heart of the Null Sector facility and end their threat for good. If a player was downed, any of the other still-surviving players could help them up by interacting with that character for a few moments (or through Mercy's Ultimate ability of Resurrection). If all four players are downed, or the explosive is destroyed before reaching the sealed doors, the round ends as a loss.<ref name="Polygon: Uprising"/><ref name="PC Gamer: Uprising"/> A separate mode allowed players to complete the same mission without being limited in character selection, but without any of the character-specific dialogue; Blizzard added this based on feedback from Junkenstein's Revenge, so as to provide a less restrictive way to enjoy the game mode.<ref name="Kotaku: Uprising"/>
The Uprising mode was considered a much-improved version of a player-versus-environment mode compared to Junkenstein's Revenge from the Halloween event. Cecilia D'Anastasio for ''[[Kotaku]]'' felt the mode was much more dynamic since it required players to move throughout the map rather than stay in one general location, and as the four default characters represent a balanced team, the mode calls for more careful teamwork and strategy. D'Anastasio also felt that with new voice lines to support this mode, it helped to establish the game's lore for players.<ref name="Kotaku: Uprising Review"/> ''PC Gamer'' argued that the Uprising event demonstrated the potential for a strong team-based story-driven campaign developed within the ''Overwatch'' narrative.<ref name="PC Gamer: Uprising Review"/>
The event had mistakenly ended a few hours earlier than expected on May 1, 2017; Blizzard apologized and extended the event for an additional day into May 2 to allow players to finish acquiring and purchasing the event loot boxes and skins.<ref name="Polygon: Uprising Ended"/>
While the event was just named "Uprising" at its release, Blizzard stated in 2018 that they considered it to be the first "''Overwatch'' Archive" annual event that will be used to explore the history of the characters and narrative.<ref name="polygon archives"/>
=== Anniversary === The Anniversary event, ran from the end of May 2017, celebrated ''Overwatch''{{'}}s first year since release. Gameplay-wise, it added three new Arena maps used for the smaller-scale Elimination games, and which will remain in rotation after the events' conclusion. The Eliminate mode also received two variants. In one-on-one "Limited Duel" matches, each player is presented with the same selection of three random heroes for play for that round. In three-on-three "Lockout Elimination", the heroes used by the winning team on a round are locked out for the next round.<ref name="Eurogamer: Anniversary"/>
In addition, over one hundred new cosmetic items are available, including new dancing emotes for each of the characters.<ref name="Eurogamer: Anniversary"/> The dance emotes were found to evoke references to popularized dance moves in other works, such as Mei's dance being similar to the "Hare Hare Yukai" dance used at the end credits for the anime ''[[The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya]]''.<ref name="Polygon: Anniversary Dance"/><ref name="Polygon: Anniversary Dance 2"/>
=== Summer Games 2017 === A second Summer Games event was held from August 8 to August 29, 2017.<ref name="VG247: Summer 2017"/> This event brought back the 3-on-3 soccer-like mode, Lucioball, introduced from the first Summer Games, adding additional arenas for the event to be played in, but removing the ability to "boop" other players.<ref name="Polygon: Summer 2017"/> In addition to casual matchmaking for Lucioball, Blizzard also introduced a ranked play system for Lucioball, separate from the game's normal Competitive mode. By participating in this "Copa Lucioball" mode, players earned Competitive Points (CP), the same in-game currency earned playing Competitive matches, and used towards purchasing special weapon skins (such as golden weapons).<ref name="VG247: Summer 2017"/><ref name="VG247: Summer 2017 Skins"/>
The previous skins and other cosmetic items offered from the first Summer Games were made available again to obtain in loot crates or purchasable from in-game coins at a lower cost, while additional Summer Games skins were added, purchasable at their normal cost.<ref name="VG247: Summer 2017 Skins"/>
=== Halloween Terror 2017 === The Halloween Terror 2017 event ran from October 10 to November 2, 2017. The event brought back "Junkenstein's Revenge" from the previous year's event, but added an endless-mode variant that challenges players to defend the door through as many waves as possible. This mode allowed players to have four additional characters to select from, Genji, Torbjorn, Widowmaker, and Zenyatta, in addition to McCree, Soldier: 76, Ana, and Hanzo. Teams lasting the longest were tracked via an online scoreboard.<ref name="VG247: Halloween 2017"/>
New skins and cosmetic items were added to the event, along with the items from the previous Halloween Terror. With the exclusion of the tombstone victory poses introduced in the previous event, all these could be obtained from loot boxes or in-game coin purchase. Blizzard opted to remove the tombstone victory poses from loot box rewards as they believed these no longer fit with the characters' personalities, but still allowed players to purchase them in-game.<ref name="Dot Esports: Halloween 2017"/>
=== Winter Wonderland 2017 === The winter-focused "Winter Wonderland 2017" event ran from December 12, 2017 through January 1, 2018. It brought back the previous year's "Winter Wonderland" content, including the "Mei Snowball Offensive" mode and previous cosmetic items, along with new skins and other cosmetics. It also added a new Arcade mode, "Yeti Hunter". In this [[asymmetric gameplay|asymmetric mode]], five players, each playing as [[Mei (Overwatch)|Mei]], attempt to defeat one player controlling [[Winston (Overwatch)|Winston]] (acting as the Yeti) in a boss battle on Nepal's Village stage. Yeti Hunt is the first Overwatch mode to use role selection; players can indicate their preference to play as a Mei or as the Yeti. The Winston player must elude the Mei team, which can freeze him, use ice walls to impede his movement, or catch him in a snare trap (which replaces Mei's usual Ultimate). After collecting four pieces of meat, which spawn randomly in predetermined locations around the map, Winston unleashes his Ultimate ability for a short period which temporarily boosts his health, reduces his jump cooldown, and gives him powerful melee attacks. When a Mei player dies, they will respawn after a short delay and cost their team a life. The match is over once the Mei team either defeats Winston or loses all five of their lives.<ref name="Kotaku: Winter 2017"/> Kaplan described the Yeti Hunt as a light-hearted mode to be played for a few matches rather than hundreds of hours.<ref name="PCGamesN: Winter 2017"/>
== 2018 events == === Year of the Dog === The Chinese New Year event reoccurred from February 8 to March 5, 2018, now reflecting the Year of the [[Dog (zodiac)|Dog]].<ref name="PCGamesN: Winter 2017"/><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/glixel/features/lunar-new-year-seasonal-event-returns-to-overwatch-next-week-w516267 | title = Lunar New Year Seasonal Event Returns to 'Overwatch' Next Week | first = Brian | last = Crecente | date = February 1, 2018 | accessdate = February 1, 2018 | work = [[Glixel]] }}</ref> New cosmetic items relating to the theme were released, in addition to the existing cosmetics from the previous event. A new map, "Ayutthaya", inspired by [[Thailand]] and specifically designed for the Capture the Flag mode, was introduced in this event. Additionally, new Capture the Flag rules for all modes were updated, replacing the potential to have these end as draws by instead playing tie-breaking rounds with the teams' flags starting closer to each other on each subsequent round. The changes also eliminated the short period before players could pick up the flag, now able to pick up the flag instantaneously, but any use of a character's active skills or ultimate abilities that provide mobility or invulnerability would force them to drop the flag, and render the flag unable to be picked up for a few moments. These changes were to make games feel "much more offensive, and much more action-packed".<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.destructoid.com/this-week-s-year-of-the-dog-event-in-overwatch-will-bring-a-new-map-486573.phtml | title = This week's Year of the Dog event in Overwatch will bring a new map | first = Jordan | last = Devore | date = February 6, 2018 | accessdate = February 6, 2018 | work = [[Destructoid]] }}</ref> Additionally, a competitive mode for Capture the Flag, following a similar format as the competitive Lucioball mode in the 2017 Summer Games event, was run during the event, rewarding players with Competitive Points and unique items for the end-of-event placement.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/glixel/news/overwatch-celebrates-lunar-new-year-with-new-map-w516551 | title = 'Overwatch' Celebrates Lunar New Year With New Map and Capture The Flag Mode | first = Blake | last= Hester | date = February 9, 2018 | accessdate = February 9, 2018 | work = [[Glixel]] }}</ref>
As part of the event, Blizzard featured its inaugural "Puppy Rumble", modeled after the ''[[Puppy Bowl]]'', on February 19, 2018, featuring puppies dressed in ''Overwatch'' character outfits in mock events. All of the animals during the event were put up for adoption through the event's co-sponsor [[Petfinder]], as well as promoting animal adoption through other local adoption agencies.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.pcgamer.com/the-overwatch-puppy-rumble-celebrates-the-year-of-the-dog-with-real-dogs/ | title = The Overwatch 'Puppy Rumble' celebrates the Year of the Dog with real dogs | first = Andy | last = Chalk | date = February 19, 2018 | accessdate = February 19, 2018 | work = [[PC Gamer]] }}</ref>
=== ''Overwatch'' Archive: Retribution === The ''Overwatch'' Archive event from the previous year returned, and ran from April 10, 2018. It brought back the narrative-driven player-versus-environment mode introduced in Uprising. It also featured a new mode titled "Retribution", which will take place on a new map, Rialto, which entered the game's map rotation as a Payload map outside of the Retribution event, on May 3, 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.gamespot.com/articles/overwatchs-new-map-rialto-is-launching-this-week-f/1100-6458660/ | title = Overwatch's New Map, Rialto, Is Launching This Week For Everyone | first =Eddie | last = Makuch | date = May 1, 2018 | accessdate = May 1, 2018 | work = [[GameSpot]] }}</ref> This was a four-player co-operative mode, based on the characters Reaper, McCree, Moira, and Genji as they escape from Talon forces; alternatively, this mode also includes an All-Hero mode where players can select any of the available characters. New skins and cosmetic items were available in loot boxes during this time.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2018/3/29/17176928/overwatch-uprising-event-start-date-2018 | title = Overwatch’s Uprising event returns in April | first = Allegra | last= Frank |date = March 29, 2018 | accessdate = March 29, 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref><ref name="polygon archives">{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2018/4/2/17189214/overwatch-archives-retribution-uprising-event | title = Overwatch’s Uprising event returns as Overwatch Archives | first= Ryan | last = Gilliam | date = April 2, 2018 | accessdate = April 2, 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.heroesneverdie.com/2018/4/4/17193808/overwatch-archives-retribution-trailer-reveal-pve | title = Overwatch Archives: Retribution is this year’s Blackwatch PVE brawl | first= Ryan | last = Gillian | date = April 4, 2018 | accessdate =April 4, 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref> The new Retribution event was aimed to provide a more replayable experience compared to the prior Uprising event. This included eliminating the waypoint approach they as to reduce elements on the user interface and instead allow players to naturally figure out how to progress in the mission. They also included "specials", unique enemies with special abilities to pose an immediate threat to the players rather than just waves of strong enemies, and included an enemy [[artificial intelligence]] systems to better react to players, including in the All-Hero mode. Much of the ideas of this mode were based on concepts from the ''[[Left 4 Dead]]'' games.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.pcgamesn.com/overwatch/overwatch-retribution-development-heroes-specials-hanzo | title = Left 4 Dead was "a huge inspiration" for Overwatch Retribution | first = Matt | last= Purslow | date = April 12, 2018 | accessdate = April 12, 2018 | work = [[PCGamesN]] }}</ref>
=== Anniversary 2018 === The second anniversary event ran from May 22 to June 11, 2018. Also with new cosmetic items, the event included a limited time competitive [[deathmatch]] mode with an exclusive map, Petra. In addition to previous Anniversary cosmetic items, all Anniversary loot boxes included cosmetic items from all previous seasonal events, and these are also available to buy with in-game gold.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.heroesneverdie.com/2018/5/14/17348534/overwatch-second-anniversary-event-cosmetics-deathmatch-details | title = Overwatch’s second anniversary event starts May 22 | first = Cass | last = Marshall | date = May 15, 2018 | accessdate = May 15, 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Heroes Never Die]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.gamespot.com/articles/new-overwatch-skins-and-more-out-now-with-annivers/1100-6459128/ | title = New Overwatch Skins And More Out Now With Anniversary Event | first= Patrick | last= Faller | date = May 24, 2018 | accessdate = May 24, 2018 | work = [[GameSpot]] }}</ref>
=== Summer Games 2018 === The third Summer Games event ran from August 9–30, 2018. The Lucioball event returned with a new stadium map based on [[Busan, South Korea]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.heroesneverdie.com/2018/8/2/17646222/overwatch-summer-games-2018-august-9th | title= Overwatch’s Summer Games return August 9th | first = Cass | last = Marshall | date = August 2, 2018 | accessdate = August 2, 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Heroes Never Die]] }}</ref>
=== Halloween Terror 2018 === The 2018 iteration of Halloween terror ran from October 10–31, 2018. The Dr. Junkenstein's Revenge mode was updated to include changes made throughout the previous year, such as the changes to Symmetra. The player-versus-environment map remained largely unchanged, with the 2 modes and 4 difficulties each of the last year's event. Brigitte and Tracer were made playable for the game mode.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.heroesneverdie.com/2018/10/1/17922306/overwatch-halloween-terror-2018-event-date | title = Halloween Terror returns to Overwatch on October 9 | first = Cass | last = Marshall | date = October 1, 2018 | accessdate = October 1, 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Heroes Never Die]] }}</ref>

{{Infobox Person | name = Precious Moloi-Motsepe | image = Precious Moloi-Motsepe heads the Mosepe Family Foundation in South Africa.jpg | image_size = | caption = in 2009 at the [[World Economic Forum]] | birth_name = Precious Moloi | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Soweto]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = | known_for = head of Motsepe Family Foundation | education = [[Wits University]] | employer = | occupation = | religion = | spouse = [[Patrice Motsepe]] | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | nationality = [[South Africa]] }} Dr '''Precious Moloi-Motsepe''' is a [[South Africa]] fashion entrepreneur and a philanthropist. Her company ran the [[Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week]] in Johannesburg and Cape Town.
==Life== Moloi-Motsepe was brought up in [[Soweto]]. Her father was a teacher and her mother was a nurse.<ref name="award">{{Cite news|url=https://www.fin24.com/Opinion/winning-women-revving-africas-engine-20170903-2|title=Winning Women: Revving Africa’s engine|work=Fin24|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref> She attended [[University of the Witwatersrand|Wits University]] and became a hospital physician and general practitioner. In 1993 she opened a women’s health clinic in Johannesburg.<ref name=award/>
In 1989, she married [[Patrice Motsepe]], a lawyer who was also brought up in [[Soweto]].
''Forbes'' Magazine estimated her family's wealth at $2.5 billion and noted that they were South Africa's wealthiest black couple. They have said that they intend to donate half their wealth to charity.<ref name="mag">{{Cite web|url=https://www.africa.com/africas-top-power-couples/|title=Africa’s Top Power Couples|website=www.africa.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref>
She was the head of the Motsepe Family Foundation in 2017. She has a strong interest in fashion and in 2007 she founded an organisation called [[African Fashion International]] which encourages young South African designers. She ran the [[Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week]] in her home city and in [[Cape Town]].<ref name="ten">{{Cite news|url=https://www.channel24.co.za/The-Juice/News/dr-precious-moloi-motsepe-celebrates-a-decade-of-fashion-with-afi-20170326|title=Dr Precious Moloi-Motsepe celebrates a decade of fashion with AFI|work=Channel|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en}}</ref> In 2017, the Cape Town event was abandoned by Moloi-Motsepe after high winds in March and rescheduled for the following April.<ref name="huff">{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2017/03/25/mercedes-benz-fashion-week-cape-town-was-a-windy-mess_a_22011784/|title=Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Cape Town Was A Windy Mess|date=2017-03-25|work=Huffington Post South Africa|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-ZA}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Moloi-Motsepe, Precious}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Soweto]] [[Category:South African physicians]] [[Category:University of the Witwatersrand alumni]] [[Category:Event management]] [[Category:South African women in business]] [[Category:21st-century South African businesspeople]]

{{Use mdy dates|date = December 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Rene van Helsdingen|image = rene in 2008-14-03.jpg |caption = Rene van Helsdingen in 2008 |image_size = |background = non_vocal_instrumentalist|birth_name = Rene Peter Onno Rubiono|alias = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1957|02|25}} |birth_place = Jakarta, Indonesia |death_date = |instrument = Piano|genre = [[jazz]] |occupation = Pianist, composer, organizer |years_active = 1975–present|label = |associated_acts = |website = {{URL|http://www.renevanhelsdingen.com/}} }} '''Rene Peter Onno Rubiono van Helsdingen''' (born 25 February 1957){{cite web|last = Helsdingen|first = Rene|url = http://www.renevanhelsdingen.com/biography.html|title = Rene van Helsdingen biography|publisher = |date = |accessdate = }} is a Dutch pianist and composer. He studied classical music with Komter Loeber in [[Blaricum]] in the Netherlands from 1962–72. Then he studied jazz music with [[Terry Trotter]] and Lazlo Cser in Los Angeles in 1979. His earliest influences include [[Oscar Peterson]], [[McCoy Tyner]] and [[Bill Evans]]. Over the years pianist René has recorded and produced for many different labels, such as Virgin, Timeless, WEA, Dureco, Zebra Acoustic, Pacific Music, Turning Point records, Munich Records, demajors Independent Music Industry Jakarta and his own labels: Relukreul records, and Helsdingen Music, The Netherlands. Helsdingen writes most of his repertoire. Australian newspaper ''[[The Age]]'' characterised him as "A rewarding pianist who can play comfortably in the groove, or create more impressionistic patterns, or quiet, subtle musings. Perhaps the most notable quality of his solos is brevity. René allows himself a few extended workouts and avoids the trap of repeating himself or overstating his case."The Age, Melbourne, 23 Dec. 1996. Helsdingen has organized many successful tours, projects and festivals sponsored by ngo’s , governmental institutions, companies to which he was responsible with regard to the control over the budgets made available. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.renevanhelsdingen.com/ Official website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Helsdingen, Rene}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Dutch pianists]] [[Category:Event management]] [[Category:Dutch composers]]

'''Shawn Rabideau''' (born February 9, 1975) is an American born lifestyle expert and event planner whose work has been featured in numerous television series including "Best Night In" on TVLand, Seasons 8 and 9 of "[[Whose Wedding Is It Anyway?]]" on the [[Style Network]].<ref name="tvwatch-people">[http://tvwatch.people.com/2010/06/23/bethenny-getting-married-wedding-planner/ People.com]</ref>
Rabideau was also cast to star in the pilot episode of "In Full Bloom" on the [[Halogen TV|Halogen Network]]. In 2010 he was the Wedding Planner for the hit series "[[Bethenny Ever After...|Bethenny Getting Married?]]" on [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo]], and in 2011 he was cast in the second season of "Bethenny Getting Married?", retitled "[[Bethenny Ever After...]]" on [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo]].<ref name="salon">[http://www.salon.com/entertainment/tv/bethenny_getting_married/?story=/ent/tv/heather_havrilesky/2010/07/03/bethenny_gets_married Salon.com]</ref>
Rabideau is widely recognized for his eye for design and has worked with numerous celebrities including [[Barbara Walters]], [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Star Jones]], and [[Bethenny Frankel]]. He has served as the lifestyle expert for [[WHAM-TV|ABC 13]] and has been a featured wedding expert on ABC's "Good Morning America,". Recently Rabideau has been a featured lifestyle and entertaining expert on VH1's "Big Morning Buzz", TV Land's "Best Night In", Better TV, CBS WLNY's "Live from the Couch" and Fox News Live where he is known for his entertaining "Rabidos" and "Rabidon'ts". He has developed a design sense that has been portrayed in magazines and newspapers including ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The New York Post]]'', ''[[Woman's World|Women's World]]'' and ''[[OK! Magazine]]''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|1=http://www.shawnrabideau.com/}} * {{imdb name|3227538}} * [http://www.bravotv.com/bethenny-getting-married/blogs/shawn-rabideau/stuck-on-the-damn-cake Shawn Rabideau blog] at [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo TV]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rabideau, Shawn}} [[Category:American television personalities]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Event planners]]

revision.text:
[[File:Solomon Curve.png|thumb|right|The Solomon curve as published in [http://openlibrary.org/books/OL5932445M/Accidents_on_main_rural_highways_related_to_speed_driver_and_vehicle "Accidents on main rural highways related to speed, driver, and vehicle"]]]
The '''Solomon curve''' is a [[graphical representation]] of the collision rate of automobiles as a function of their speed compared to the average vehicle speed on the same road. The curve was based on [[research]] conducted by David Solomon in the late 1950s and published in 1964.<ref>{{cite news | first=David | last=Solomon | title=Accidents on main rural highways related to speed, driver, and vehicle | date=July 1964, Reprinted 1974 | publisher=Technical report, U.S. Department of Commerce/Bureau of Public Roads (precursor to Federal Highway Administration)| work = | pages = }}</ref> Subsequent research suggests significant biases in the Solomon study, which may cast doubt on its findings.<ref>{{cite news | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement on Rural Roads | date=July 2001 | publisher=Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/ruralspeed/RURALSPEED.PDF}}</ref>
== The original research == In 1964, Solomon researched the relationship between [[average]] [[speed]] and the [[collision]] [[Rate (mathematics)|rates]] of [[automobile]]s and plotted the results.<ref>{{cite book | last = Meyer | first = John Robert | authorlink = |author2=José A. Gómez-Ibáñez |author3=William B. Tye |author4=Clifford Winston | title = Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy | publisher = Brookings Institution Press | date = February 1999 | location = | pages = 275 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=MFhkehz-Ky0C&pg=PA257&dq=%22Solomon+curve%22 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8157-3181-8 }}</ref> While others have attempted to quantify the relationship between average speed and collision rates, Solomon's work was both "the earliest and best known".<ref name="Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement">{{cite web | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/speed/vol-1.html | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement |pages=Section 2.1 | accessdate=3-1-2009 |vauthors=Kloeden CN, McLean AJ, Moore VM, Ponte G | date=November 1997| publisher= | quote=}}</ref> Solomon conducted a comprehensive study of more than 10,000 collision-involved drivers and their vehicles and how other roadway, driver, and vehicle characteristics affect the probability of being involved in a crash.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cost-Benefit Evaluation of Large Truck- Automobile Speed Limit Differentials on Rural Interstate Highways|journal=University of Arkansas, Department of Industrial Engineering|date=November 2005|first=Steven L.|last=Johnson|author2=Naveen Pawar|volume=|issue=|pages=Page 24|id=|url=http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|format=MS Word|accessdate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051900/http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|archivedate=2011-07-27|df=}}</ref> He found that the probability of being involved in a crash per vehicle-mile as a function of on-road vehicle speeds follows a U-shaped curve with speed values around the median speed having the lowest probability of being in a crash.<ref>{{Cite book| first=Kuei-Yuan | last=Chan|author2=Steven J. Skerlos |author3=Panos Y. Papalambros | contribution=A CASE STUDY IN VEHICLE EMISSIONS REGULATIONS TO ACHIEVE AMBIENT AIR QUALITY STANDARDS| title=Proceedings of IDETC/CIE 2006| editor-first=| editor-last=| publisher=ASME| place=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania| pages=8| date=2006-09-10| id= | contribution-url=http://ode.engin.umich.edu/publications/PapalambrosPapers/2006/231.pdf| format=PDF| accessdate=2009-03-01| editors= }}</ref> Although typically called the Solomon curve, the U-shaped curve has also been referred to as the Crash Risk Curve.<ref name="Is speed killing us?">{{cite web | url=http://www.sense.bc.ca/research.htm | title=Is speed killing us? | accessdate=3-1-2009 | author=Society for Safety by Education Not Speed Enforcement | quote=}}</ref>
== Subsequent research == In 1968, Julie Cirillo conducted a similar study of 2,000 vehicles on interstate highways that addressed speed variation’s impact on crashes that involved two or more vehicles.<ref>{{cite book | last = Cirillo |first=J. A.|title = Interstate System Accident Research Study II, Interim Report II, Public Roads, 35 (3) |year = 1968|pages = 71–75 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> The Cirillo data produced a U-shaped curve similar to the Solomon curve.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cost-Benefit Evaluation of Large Truck- Automobile Speed Limit Differentials on Rural Interstate Highways|journal=University of Arkansas, Department of Industrial Engineering|date=November 2005|first=Steven L.|last=Johnson|author2=Naveen Pawar|volume=|issue=|pages=Page 25|id=|url=http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|format=MS Word|accessdate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051900/http://ww2.mackblackwell.org/web/research/ALL_RESEARCH_PROJECTS/2000s/2048/Final%20MBTC%20Report%202048%2011-8.doc|archivedate=2011-07-27|df=}}</ref> The [[Research Triangle Institute]] conducted a study in 1970 where data was collected on 114 crashes involving 216 vehicles on a state highway in Indiana to address these concerns by (1) combining automated, embedded speed-monitoring stations with trained on-scene crash investigators, and (2) distinguishing data on vehicles slowing to negotiate a turn from vehicles moving slowly in the flow of traffic.<ref>Research Triangle Institute, "Speed and Accident, Volume II," Report No. FH-11-6965, National Highway Safety Bureau, June 1970.</ref> Reporting on these results in 1971, academics West and Dunn confirmed the findings of Solomon and Cirillo,<ref name="Impacts and Issues Related to Proposed Changes in Oregon’s Interstate Speed Limits">{{cite web | url=http://www.its.pdx.edu/speedlimits/final%20interstate%20speed%20review%20report%20(9.12).pdf | title=Impacts and Issues Related to Proposed Changes in Oregon’s Interstate Speed Limits | accessdate=3-1-2009 | author=Monsere, C. M., Newgard, C., Dill, J. Rufolo, A., Wemple, E., Bertini, R. L., and Milliken, C. | date=September 2004 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6H4UFKRFH?url=http://www.its.pdx.edu/speedlimits/final%20interstate%20speed%20review%20report%20%289.12%29.pdf | archivedate=2013-06-02 | df= }}</ref> but found that crashes involving turning vehicles accounted for 44 percent of all crashes observed in the study and that excluding these crashes from the analysis greatly attenuated the factors that created the U-shape of the Solomon curve.<ref>West, L. B., Jr. and Dunn, J. W. (1971). "Accidents, Speed Deviation and Speed Limits." Traffic Engineering. 41 (10), 52-55</ref>
In 1991, Fildes, Rumbold, and Leening collected self-reported crash data from 707 motorists in Australia with fewer than 200 reporting that they had been in a collision but, unlike Solomon and Cirillo, the researchers found no relationship between slower speeds and increased crash involvement.<ref name="Speed Behaviour and Drivers’ Attitude to Speeding">{{cite web | url=http://www.monash.edu.au/muarc/reports/muarc016.html | title=Speed Behaviour and Drivers’ Attitude to Speeding | accessdate=3-2-2009 |vauthors=Fildes BN, Rumbold G, Leening A | date=June 1991 | location = Monash University Accident Research Centre, Victoria Australia, | quote=}}</ref> Notwithstanding the many studies over the years, in testimony before the Ohio Senate Highways and Transportation Committee on June 10, 2003, Julie Cirillo, Former Assistant Administrator and Chief Safety Officer for the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration ([[FMCSA]]), testified that "up to the present time there has been no evidence to alter Solomon’s original finding that variance from the mean operating speed is a major contributor to accidents".<ref name="Testimonyof2003">{{cite news|title=Testimony of Julie Anna Cirillo |date=2003-06-10 |publisher=OOIDA |url=http://www.landlinemag.com/Special_Reports/2003/June03/Cirillo_Testimony.htm |work=Land Line Magazine |pages= |accessdate=2009-03-02 |language= |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040816035301/http://www.landlinemag.com/Special_Reports/2003/June03/Cirillo_Testimony.htm |archivedate=August 16, 2004 }}</ref>
In July 2001, Kloeden CN, Ponte G and McLean AJ of the Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University quantified the relationship, "... between free travelling speed and the risk of involvement in a casualty crash in 80 km/h or greater speed limit zones in rural South Australia" using a case control study design. They found, "..the risk of involvement in a casualty crash increased more than exponentially with increasing free travelling speed above the mean traffic speed and that travelling speeds below the mean traffic speed were associated with a lower risk of being involved in a casualty crash." Outlining past research in this area, they suggest that, in the Solomon research, "Both the numerator (number of crashes in a particular speed band) and the denominator (number of vehicle-miles travelled in that same speed band) may have been quite inaccurate for relatively low speeds." <ref>{{cite news | title=Travelling Speed and the Risk of Crash Involvement on Rural Roads | date=July 2001 | publisher=Road Accident Research Unit, Adelaide University | url=http://casr.adelaide.edu.au/ruralspeed/RURALSPEED.PDF}}</ref>
== Theoretical foundation == Hauer provided a theoretical foundation for the Solomon curve in 1971—“for example, if I drive at 45 mph, while the [[median]] of the pack is 60 mph, how many cars will pass me in an hour and hence have a chance to collide with me?”—that showed that the theoretical [[Frequency distribution|distribution]] was nearly identical to the Solomon curve.<ref name="Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MFhkehz-Ky0C&pg=PA276&lpg=PA276&dq=%22The+Solomon+Curve%22 | title=Essays in Transportation Economics and Policy | accessdate=3-1-2009 |author1=John Robert Meyer |author2=José A. Gómez-Ibáñez |author3=William B. Tye |author4=Clifford Winston | pages=Page 276 | isbn=978-0-8157-3181-8 | date=1999-02}}</ref>
== Practical implications == While Solomon’s research focused on speed deviation, and not speed per se, some commentators have cited Solomon’s research to support the conclusion that raw speed and crash risk are not directly related.<ref name="Is speed killing us?"/> On the other hand, while recognizing Solomon's research reveals the importance to safety of variability around average speed, Leonard Evans concludes in ''[[Traffic Safety and the Driver]]'' that control of absolute driver speed, and not variability, should be the primary focus of traffic safety regulation.<ref>{{cite book | last = Evans | first = Leonard| title = Traffic Safety and the Driver | publisher = Van Nostrand Reinhold | year = 1991 | location = New York, New York | pages = 155–56 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=OyuGJJ6rKQ0C&pg=PA155&lpg=PA155&dq=%22Traffic+Safety+and+the+Driver%22+Solomon| isbn = 0-442-00163-0 }}</ref> Both views support the fact that the seminal research underlying the Solomon curve shows that the greater the difference between a driver’s speed and the average speed of traffic—both above and below that average speed—the greater the likelihood of involvement in a crash.<ref>{{cite book | last = Transportation Research Board | first = Committee for Guidance on Setting and Enforcing Speed Limits | title = Managing Speed | publisher = National Research Council (U.S.) | year = 1998 | location = | pages = 46 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pARs53U6NAQC&pg=PA224&dq=%22drive+with+the+flow+of+traffic”+Solomon | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-309-06502-X }}</ref> Consequently, many states and safety organizations advise drivers to “drive with the flow of traffic”.<ref name="Testimonyof2003" />
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead]] * [[Automobile safety]] * [[Car accident]] * [[Design speed]] * [[Operating speed]] * [[Road-traffic safety]] * [[Speed limit]] * [[Traffic engineering (transportation)]] * [[Traffic psychology]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Car safety]] [[Category:Causes of death]] [[Category:Traffic collisions]] [[Category:Road safety]]

{{Infobox podcast | title = The Fifth Column Podcast | image = The_Fifth_Column_Podcast_Logo.jpg | host = Kmele Foster, Matt Welch, Michael C. Moynihan | genre = News & Politics | format = MP3 | updates = Weekly | length = 50-120 mins | language = English | began = Apr 1, 2016 | website = {{URL|http://wethefifth.com}} }}
'''The Fifth Column Podcast''' is an American politics, news and humor podcast founded in April, 2016. The show is hosted by [[Kmele Foster]], with co-hosts [[Michael C. Moynihan]], [[Matt Welch]] and produced by contributor [https://www.anthonylfisher.com/ Anthony L. Fisher] and Daniel Bier. The podcast is described as in each episode as an “...almost weekly thoughtful commentary on the news, those who make it and occasionally ourselves”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wethefifth.com/episodes/2018/3/12/stormy-social-media-q-mdf8t-gwmfc-mlw4s-dlwdt-xxtzd-psbc3-xmyrf-6ml8a-bgcn4-ns82z-ny8yb-ww44l-sr9ce-2zhfh-3zbfs-ez68r-zsjyw-ymsts-glnfc-p77pw-mwa47-hb2fy-85b74|title=116 w/ Harry Siegel "Soros' Paid Protest Mobs, Team Woke vs Team Resentment"|last=|first=|date=|website=wethefifth.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The show is closely associated with independent-leaning, libertarian and anarcho-capitalist ideology as presented by the show hosts and guests, but is not explicitly so.
=== Background and Format === '''[http://wethefifth.com/ The Fifth Column Podcast]''' first aired on iTunes April 2, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column-analysis-commentary-sedition/id1097696129?mt=2|title=The Fifth Column Podcast - iTunes|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The show markets itself as “Analysis. Commentary. Sedition” on Instagram<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/we.the.fifth/|title=The Fifth Column Podcast - Instagram|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and as “@MattWelch @mcmoynihan @Kmele pick apart the news, interrogate their guests and question just about everything #someidiotwrotethis” on Twitter<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/wethefifth|title=wethefifth - Twitter|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The introduction to the podcast typically describes itself as: “…your almost weekly rhetorical assault on the news cycle, the people who make it and occasionally ourselves…”. Credit for the shows creation has been attributed to the encouragement of [[Kennedy (commentator)|Kennedy]] (Lisa Kennedy Montgomery) and her husband Dave Lee, who are associates of the hosts. The name of the podcast has been attributed to a suggestion by [[Katherine Mangu-Ward]] as revealed in Episode 13 (3:05 mark)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-fifth-column-analysis-commentary-sedition/id1097696129?mt=2|title="Islamic [REDACTED] and OJ Simpson"|last=|first=|date=June 21, 2016|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The original music that opens and closes the podcast includes a soundbite of F.D.R.’s speech given 1940/05/27 warning prejudices exploited by Fifth [[iarchive:1940-05-27_FDR_Warns_of_Fifth_Column|Columnists]]. (https:archive.org)
=== Reception === ''Reason.com'' regularly promotes The Fifth Column in its ''Hit & Run'' segments<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reason.com/blog/2016/04/01/whose-foreign-policy-is-really-dumb-the|title=Whose Foreign Policy Is Really Dumb; the Elephant Man Theory of Beauty Pageants, and ‘Some Idiot Wrote This’—Introducing The Fifth Column Podcast|last=Welch|first=Matt|date=April 1, 2016|website=www.reason.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. Other promotions come by way of wearelibertarians.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wearelibertarians.com/libertarian-podcasts/|title=My Top 10 Libertarian Podcasts|last=Spangle|first=Chris|date=July 4, 2016|website=wearelibertarians.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, rampantdiscourse.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rampantdiscourse.com/things-i-like-podcasts/|title=Things I Like: Podcasts|last=Essen|first=Paul|date=November 23, 2016|website=rampantdiscourse.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, postlibertarian.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://postlibertarian.com/tag/the-fifth-column/|title=Trump Junior and Russia|last=|first=|date=July 15, 2017|website=postlibertarian.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and freedombunker.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://freedombunker.com/2017/05/19/should-we-even-care-about-trump-scandals-and-russia-michael-moynihan-and-thad-russell-duke-it-out-on-the-fifth-column/|title=Should we even care about Trump scandals and Russia? Michael Moynihan and Thad Russell duke it on on The Fifth Column|last=|first=|date=May 19, 2017|website=freedombunker.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
